text: General elections were held in Sweden on 20 September 1964.Nohlen, D & Stöver, P (2010) Elections in Europe: A data handbook, p1858 The Swedish Social Democratic Party remained the largest party, winning 113 of the 233 seats in the Second Chamber of the Riksdag.Nohlen & Stöver, p1872 Tage Erlander's Social Democratic government was returned to power. ==Results== {| class=wikitable style=text-align:right |- |colspan=7|300px |- !Party !Votes !% !Seats !+/– |- |align=left|Swedish Social Democratic Party||2,006,923||47.3||113||–1 |- |align=left|People's Party||720,733||17.0||43||+3 |- |align=left|Rightist Party||582,609||13.7||33||–6 |- |align=left|Centre Party||559,632||13.2||35||+1 |- |align=left|Communist Party of Sweden||221,746||5.2||8||+3 |- |align=left|Christian Democratic Unity||75,389||1.8||0||New |- |align=left|Civic Unity||64,807||1.5||1||New |- |align=left|Middle Parties||13,557||0.3||0||New |- |align=left|Other parties||384||0.0||0||0 |- |align=left|Invalid/blank votes||27,815||–||–||– |- |align=left|Total||4,273,595||100||233||+1 |- |align=left|Registered voters/turnout||5,095,850||83.9||–||– |- |align=left colspan=5|Source: Nohlen & Stöver |} Civic Unity was a joint list of the three right-wing parties in Malmö. One of its elected candidates was a member of the Centre Party, but sat as an independent. The Middle Parties was a joint list of the Centre Party and People's Party that contested some constituencies.Nohlen & Stöver, p1861 ==References== 1964 Category:1964 elections in Europe Category:1964 in Sweden Category:September 1964 events
title: 1964 Swedish general election
